user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CloseFileByName:
```c
int32 OS_CloseFileByName(const char *Filename)
{
    int32                        return_code;
    int32                        close_code;
    OS_object_iter_t             iter;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Filename);

    return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;

    OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);

    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, iter.token);

        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID && (strcmp(stream->stream_name, Filename) == 0))
        {
            /* call OS_close() on the entry referred to by the iterator */
            close_code = OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(&iter, OS_FileIteratorClose);

            if (return_code == OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID || close_code != OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                return_code = close_code;
            }
        }
    }

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CloseFileByName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(osal_objtype_t objtype, OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ObjectFilterActive, NULL, objtype, iter);
}
...
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(OS_object_iter_t *iter, int32 (*func)(osal_id_t, void *))
{
    int32 status;

    /*
     * This needs to temporarily unlock the global,
     * call the handler function, then re-lock.
     */
    OS_Unlock_Global(&iter->token);
    status = func(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(&iter->token), iter->arg);
    OS_Lock_Global(&iter->token);

    return status;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(&iter->token);
}
...
int32 OS_FileIteratorClose(osal_id_t filedes, void *arg)
{
    return OS_close(filedes);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler language extensions in the provided code fragments. The following checks were performed and justify not flagging any fragment:

- No compiler-specific tokens are present: there are no occurrences of __attribute__, __asm__, __extension__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }) used as expressions, nested functions, or labels-as-values — all of which are common explicitly-documented compiler extensions.

- Macros used in the function are standard macro usages. OS_CHECK_POINTER is a macro invocation; its expansion shown is a call to BUGCHECK, but the BUGCHECK implementation is not provided in the excerpts and there is no evidence in the shown code that it expands to a compiler-specific extension. The mere use of a macro is not itself an extension.

- The pointer, array indexing, address-of, and structure member operations (e.g., OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(&tbl[...]), &iter->token, stream->stream_name) are standard C.

- Declarations use typedefs (int32, osal_id_t, bool) and array of records (OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]). These are standard C constructs; the array uses a macro-sized bound (OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES) which is the normal pattern — nothing in the excerpt indicates a variable-length array or other extension.

- Function-pointer usage (OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry taking int32 (*func)(osal_id_t, void *)) and passing a matching function (OS_FileIteratorClose) are standard C.

- Lock/unlock calls and iterator logic are regular function calls and control flow; there are no inline assembly blocks or compiler pragmas present in the provided code.

Caveat: If any of the hidden macro definitions (e.g., BUGCHECK, OS_Unlock_Global, or others not fully shown) expand to compiler-specific constructs, that could be an extension — but based solely on the code and definitions provided here, there is no explicit use of documented compiler language extensions to report.
